item.title: AsyncLocal never leaks and is safe for CallContext-like state
item.description: Sometime ago I wrote on How to migrate CallContext to .NETStandard and .NETCore, and one question mentioned that the values themselves might leak, which actually is not the case, as shown here, due to the "magic" that is AsyncLocal in combination with the transient nature of the ExecutionContext:
item.dc:creator: Daniel Cazzulino

item.title: Using HashCode in .NETFramework
item.description: So, I just learned that not even in .net472/net48, you can leverage the cool HashCode type from .NETCore. It is mentioned in docs as available in ".NET Platform Extensions 3.1", which isn't quite clear what it means. After a quick search here and there, I found out the Microsoft.Bcl.HashCode package, which seems to be one such ".NET platform extension" (although the version # doesn't match either :/).
item.dc:creator: Daniel Cazzulino

item.title: How to locate dotnet
item.description: I've seen a bunch of DotNetMuxer implementations, but they all look quite similar (if not exactly the same).
item.dc:creator: Daniel Cazzulino

item.title: Conditional unit tests
item.description: Turns out that there aren't any conditional FactAttribute in xunit, but you can pretty much copy wholesale the extensions created by the ASP.NET Core team from their repo.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Cazzulino

item.title: Skip tagged scenarios in SpecFlow with Xunit
item.description: First apply a tag of your choosing to flag scenarios that are still not ready for running:
item.dc:creator: Daniel Cazzulino

item.title: How to build project when content files change
item.description: Visual Studio will typically just report the project is up-to-date and doesn't need to be built if you just changed a Content or None item. If you want it to consider those file types to also trigger a build, just add the relevant items as UpToDateCheckInput:
item.dc:creator: Daniel Cazzulino

item.title: C# script function apps beyond Azure portal
item.description: Creating a C# function app in the Azure portal is incredibly simple and great for playing and learning. I love the simplicity and light-ness that comes from just having a single .csx script file with everything you need for the function. The more "serious" approach with a "proper" C# project, the functions SDK and the corresponding CI/CD setup seems quite the leap, in comparison.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Cazzulino

item.title: Publishing function app from GitHub folder
item.description: For very simple functions, I really liked just hacking them in the Azure portal. This is super brittle, however, since changes that break the app can't be undone. Great for learning, not so much once you start depending on those functions.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Cazzulino

item.title: Exploring Azure Data with Kusto and Dashboards
item.description: In order to more effectively learn Kusto (the query language powering Azure analytics, log querying and PowerBI) and data visualization capabilites in Azure, I did the following:
item.dc:creator: Daniel Cazzulino

item.title: Shared secret authorization with Azure SignalR Service
item.description: While testing out Azure Functions development and configuration with Azure SignalR Service, I needed a very simple key-based (shared secret) authorization mechanism so that my console-based SignalR client could connect to my Azure SignalR Service-powered hub using a very simple mechanism.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Cazzulino

item.description: Oh boy, did I waste time on this one :(. So I had my pipeline pretty naively doing an upload to blob storage:
item.dc:creator: Daniel Cazzulino

item.title: Code-less redirection with serverless Azure Functions
item.description: Say you want to have a nicer URI for something (like an Azure storage blob, a feed or something else). You likely have a nice short custom domain (i.e. I use kzu.io for things like this), and would like to set up arbitrary (temporary or permanent) redirections. This can trivially be achieved by creating an empty Functions App and leveraging Functions Proxies.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Cazzulino

item.title: Update version and publish npm from GH
item.description: Super proud of this, since it's my first node.js package ever (created brand-new account on https://www.npmjs.com/ and all ðŸ˜), for doing syntax highlighting for dotnetconfig that works in docfx.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Cazzulino
